during the 4th International conference on Home Land Security and Cyber in the Israeli coastal city of Tel AvivSince the App Store arrived a year after the iPhone, in 2008, Apple has allowed people to put third-party apps onto their phone. But they have never had the same powers as Apple's own apps.Apple’s new cheaper phone 'to arrive soon' despite coronavirusThat means that users can download third-party browsers like Google's Chrome or Firefox, for instance, but that clicking on a link from a text message will always take them to Apple's own Safari. Likewise a user might have Microsoft Outlook or Gmail installed, and can use them for emails, but clicking an email link will still always bring up Apple's own Mail apps.On Android, by comparison, people are able to choose which browser, messaging app, email client or music platform they would prefer to use, and that will be set as the default. Even though Android phones come with Google apps installed, people are able to stop using them more easily.Any changes could arrive in iOS 14, Bloomberg reported. That update is likely to be revealed at Apple's WWDC event in summer, followed by a public release around September, at roughly the same time as the release of the new iPhone.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: social capital smartphones social media impacts ons
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'We feel safer walking alone after dark in our neighbourhoods, but more recently fewer of us feel like we belong to them,' says&nbspEleanor Rees, head of the ONS’ social well-being analysis teamThis may not come as a surprise to anyone living in a modern UK town or city, but Britons are interacting less with their neighbours or elderly parents and far more with their mobile phone.A detailed exercise attempting to spot changing trends in personal relationships, social network support, civic engagement, and trust points to a growing inidualism.The report by the Office for National Statistics called Social Capital in the UK: 2020 is based on 25 indicators that come mainly from self-reported survey data.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIt found the proportion of those saying they felt they belonged to their neighbourhood had fallen to 62 per cent compared with 69 per cent four years ago.The proportion who regularly stop and talk to their neighbours has also fallen relative to 2011 and 2012 from 66 per cent to 62 per cent, suggesting lower engagement within our communities.One in four young people ‘addicted to their smartphones’Also, compared with eight years ago, people were less likely to provide help to others through providing special help to sick, elderly or disabled persons or through parental links after children have left homeIn 2018, 36 per cent of adults reported regularly or frequently receiving help from their children aged 16 years or older not living with them, six percentage points lower than in 2012.Tasks included giving them lifts in their car, shopping or cooking their meals, washing, ironing or cleaning and dealing with personal affairs such as paying bills, writing letters or doing decorating, gardening or house repairs.While the findings point to a more atomised society, the ONS said the fall in parents receiving help from children not living with them could be related to more parents and adult children living together.Multi-family households consisting of two or more families were the fastest growing household type over the 10 years to 2019, which the ONS said might reflect families living together out of necessity because of housing affordability, childcare responsibilities or caring for older relatives.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailSocial media addicts 'have same personality traits' as drug addictsInstagram’s latest feature aims to tackle social media addictionIs your child ready for a smartphone?US may monitor phones of people with mental health problemsBeautiful countryside 'hides ugly truth of poverty and isolation'However, there was a clear increase in the use of social media, with 68 per cent of people saying they had used the internet for social networking in the last three months, up from just over half 53 per cent seven years ago.“Our social capital findings show that we are engaging less with our neighbours but more with social media,” said Eleanor Rees, head of the ONS’ social well-being analysis team. “We feel safer walking alone after dark in our neighbourhoods, but more recently fewer of us feel like we belong to them.”Sunder Katwala, director of independent thinktank British Future that last month joined a call for a “decade of reconnection”, said the report underlined something he said many people had felt for some time. “We have become less connected with our fellow citizens. Our society is more ided than any of us would like,” he said.“Most people would like to feel more connected with their neighbours and people in their community. But rebuilding a more connected society will take action at all levels — from the Government and institutions to communities and iniduals too. There is a public appetite for us all to play our part in ensuring we turn this around.” &nbspMeanwhile at the UK level, trust in national government fell by 11 percentage points in the year to autumn 2019 to just 21 per cent. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Mya-Rose Craig praised as inspirationalA teenage birdwatcher&nbspknown as “Birdgirl”&nbsphas become the youngest Briton ever to receive an honorary university degree.Mya-Rose Craig, 17, has been recognised for her campaigning projects to make the natural environment more accessible to people from minority ethnic backgrounds.The Bristolian, known as Birdgirl due to her Twitter username, has set up nature camps and conferences for young people and is also the youngest person to have&nbspseen half of the world’s bird species.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesProfessor Richard Pancost of the University of Bristol, who nominated Mya-Rose, said she was “most deserving” of the accolade.The earth sciences department head said:&nbsp“Although only 17, Mya-Rose has already created a phenomenal amount of positive change for nature and is a fantastic role model for her peers.“She epitomises courage in the face of resistance as she challenges the environmental sector to tackle the lack of racial and ethnic ersity.“Her enthusiasm as @BirdgirlUK has inspired so many people to take an interest in wildlife and enjoy the beauty of nature while protecting its fragility.”Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Police officers outside Regents Park mosque in central London after a man was reportedly been stabbed in the neck. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.What do you do after losing everything? May Bulman talks to those kicked out of Britain about the difficulty of&nbspstarting againImagine being ripped from everyone and everything in your life, locked in a cell, then flown across the globe to a country you barely know. You have no friends or family there, no job, and sometimes struggle to even be understood by the locals. This is your new life.That’s the situation facing some of those flown to Jamaica on a controversial charter flight this month, many of whom – though they remain Jamaican nationals – had lived in Britain since they were children. One told The Independent he had only a single&nbspmemory of the Caribbean island:&nbspbrushing his teeth as a small child.The mass deportation, which had intended to return around 50 people before the courts limited the number to 17, has shone a light on human suffering caused by Britain’s returns system, which sees thousands deported each year, often with limited access to legal help to defend their right to stay in the UK.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesOne man struggling to build a life after deportation is Tremayne Brown, 26, who was on a charter flight to Jamaica in 2017. He had lived in Britain since the age of six, having moved from Kingston’s Rose Town to south London with his father after his mother, brother and sister were killed by gangs. His father went to prison soon after their arrival – and was later deported – meaning Tremayne was put into care. No attempts were made to regularise his status in the UK.“I was leaving care and I was meant to get my own place and find a job, but then my social worker told me I wasn’t allowed to work, and they weren’t able to give me somewhere to live either, because of my status,” says Tremayne. “I was suddenly classed as an illegal alien.”Created with Sketch.Windrush generation: threat of deportation from UK Show all 15Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.The ex-troopship 'Empire Windrush' arriving at Tilbury Docks from Jamaica, with 482 Jamaicans on board, emigrating to Britain.Jamaican immigrants being welcomed by RAF officials from the Colonial Office after the ex-troopship 'Empire Windrush' landed them at Tilbury. But he was not allowed to work. His girlfriend and their baby son needed financial support, so he was pushed into crime.“I was stuck in a place where I wasn’t allowed to work and I couldn’t get anywhere to live. What am I meant to do? I regret it every day. If I didn’t do that, I would be there with my son right now.”Aged 18, Tremayne was convicted for supplying class A drugs and commercial robbery, serving three years in jail. He did his time, then was transferred to a removal centre and issued deportation orders. He says that on entering detention he was told his removal had been cancelled, so did not contact his solicitor. But a week later, he was put on a flight.“One night they came to my door and said, ‘Pack your bags.’ When I was on the plane I called the solicitor and he said, ‘Why didn’t you ring me, I could have cancelled your ticket,’ but that it was too late. I never got the opportunity to fight my case.”A young man who grew up in the hands of the British state was now being flown to a country he had not set foot in for nearly 20 years.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Though he lives with his father, Tremayne yearns to see his loved ones in Britain, particularly his son who, now aged six, has spent the majority of his life without his dad, having to make do with video calls.“He always asks me, ‘Dad, where are you?’ And if I’m coming back and why I left. It’s hard to explain it to him. He might hear his father’s voice and see him, but in reality you want him there in front of you. Through his childhood I haven’t been there. I haven’t been able to take him to the park. Those little things are important and have a knock-on effect on him as a child, having to grow up and say, ‘My father wasn’t there.’ It will make him bitter.”The Uncertain Kingdom - the groundbreaking anthology of twenty short films is released in cinemas 3&nbspApril.&nbspTremayne struggled to find work, largely because of his reputation as being one of the “deportee boys” who had their chance and lost it. His qualifications were not recognised in Jamaica, but he found a job at a holding company. He says the stigma still weighs on his shoulders. His British accent means he is constantly asked where he comes from and why he was deported.“I have had to start again from scratch. You spend your whole life in one place and then you have to adapt yourself again. Nothing is easy, but you have to try,” he says. “Some days are really hard. I miss my son, I miss my foster mum, I miss the scenery. Having been a young boy and grown up there, I class myself as British. Everything I know is from Britain. I never learned anything from Jamaica.”Another deportee, Chevon Brown, was forcibly removed on a charter flight last February on the basis of a driving offence he committed aged 21 – something he describes as a “stupid mistake”. He had moved to the UK when he was 14 and has no close relatives in Jamaica.As a qualified barber who started working at the age of 16, the 24-year-old had hoped to find a job fairly easily. But he says his name has been tarnished by the insinuation by British politicians that everyone on the charter plane was a murderer, rapist or drug dealer.Chevon rarely leaves the house because he says he can feel animosity from people in the street, and he has sleepless nights worrying about his future.“I’ve asked for jobs, told them I’m qualified, but after they’ve heard my name, they don’t want to employ me. They say how can they trust me when I’ve been deported,” he tells The Independent. “People think we’re going to come here and cause major crimes. Most people think I’m a murderer, rapist or drug trafficker, which I’m not. I went to prison for dangerous driving and I completely regret it because I never knew I’d be serving double punishment for one stupid mistake.”The proof that ministers haven’t learnt the lessons from WindrushChevon, who grew up in Oxford, served seven months after admitting speeding in an uninsured car. It happened after a heated argument with his housemate, when he took the car out and drove away from police.“I knew what I was doing was wrong in the moment,” he says. “I was genuinely scared. I wish I had stopped, given them the key, got arrested and that be that. I had no idea that this would be the aftermath of driving away from the police. If I ever come back to England I don’t want any involvement with police. I just want to live a calm and peaceful life. I want to get a barbershop, get a mortgage on a house, start planning a future, get a car, all those things.“But right now, I’m paying two, three years after the actual thing. I’ve gone to jail, done my time, and years later I still can’t actually move on with my life. I feel like I’m still in prison. It’s worse than prison, because I can’t see my family and friends. I feel like I’m stuck. My whole reputation has been messed up by one silly mistake.”“My dad is getting more and more stressed. He’s got health problems. My 18-year-old brother’s not listening to anyone any more. There’s been a ripple effect from what’s happened to me. My little brother keeps asking me, ‘When are you coming home?’ I can’t give him a definite answer about that. I wanted to set a good example. But right now I feel like I’m actually being a weight on my family, because of all this negative attention that’s been drawn towards me.“I feel more British than Jamaican. My dad brought me to England and said this was where I was going to be living for the rest of my life. So I ed into the new society and this is who I am today. Most people try to tell me to speak Patois, but I feel comfortable speaking English. When I speak the Jamaican language I feel like I have to put it on. I don’t want to put it on.”The level of contact goes down, and that just compounds the sense of lost connectionsWhile charter flights to Jamaica have garnered media attention in the wake of the Windrush scandal, forced deportations from the UK take place throughout the year to countries across the globe, with 9,461 people removed in 2018 and 12,049 the year before – in addition to around 20,000 iniduals removed through the voluntary returns route. An estimated 2,000 of those forcibly removed are put on planes privately chartered by the Home Office, of which a total of 20 charter planes left Britain last year, with the destinations including Albania, Pakistan, Nigeria, France and Ghana.Kweku Adoboli, 39, was deported to Ghana in 2018 after having lived in Britain since the age of 12. In a highly publicised court case, he had been sentenced to seven years behind bars in 2012 after losing £1.4bn while working for Swiss bank UBS. The banker, who had a British partner at the time, was sentenced to five years in jail. Two days after he was convicted, he was informed that he was liable to automatic deportation.“All the way from being arrested through to just after I was convicted immigration didn’t cross my mind. The level of stress goes through the roof,” says Kweku, who now lives with his parents in Accra. “Suddenly, the battle’s not over. I can’t just sit in and do my time and go home.“The pressure in the relationship started to go up, because now she’s thinking, ‘Okay, so I’ve stood by him through this fight, now what? What if I keep fighting if he’s going to get deported anyway?’”Kweku had left Ghana aged four, when his parents moved to the Middle East for work. He is grateful to have his parents and other relatives now in the country, but devastated at how his relationships in Britain – including with his now ex-girlfriend and many friends – have broken down since his return.“It’s the inability of being able to get on a plane and be there for someone,” he explains. “The distance creates massive tension in the relationship. You have to increasingly distance yourself from these really close relationships. The level of contact goes down, and that just compounds the sense of lost connections, which then leads to depression.”‘Cruelty’ as Jamaicans driven to charter flight despite court rulingAfter arriving in Ghana, Kweku spent about nine months sitting in his bedroom, unable to leave the house. He developed a number of physical manifestations of the trauma he had been through. “My body started to swell up a lot,” he says. “We thought it was a heart problem so had a lot of heart tests. My face just blew up like a balloon, my legs were like elephant trunks,”The Ghanaian national acknowledges that he was relatively lucky on his return that, unlike the Jamaican deportees, he was welcomed with open arms by both his family and the country as a whole, who gave him what he describes as a “massive embrace”.“Because of the violence and the cruelty of what happened to me, I think Ghana went, ‘This is a son of Ghana, a son of Africa, why should anyone be treated this way?’ Random people on the street would stop me. Everyone recognised me. They were all saying welcome home,” he says, adding: “My stamina is not back and I’m still dealing with adrenal failure, so I still have to do a lot of work to deal with my stress, but I’m getting back to the point where I’m starting to contribute again.”But Kweku still remembers what he went through on during his deportation: “Of all that I went through, none of it was as bad as sitting at the back of a plane with five G4S guards. I was hyperventilating, sobbing non-stop for four hours.”Branded “foreign national offenders” and “illegal immigrants” by the Home Office&nbspas they wait in cells to be taken away, these deportees are characterised as hardened criminals. But for Tremayne, Chevon and Kweku, these terms – and the trauma – ripple through their lives for years to come as they try to start again, thousands of miles from the place they call home.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - There’s nothing wrong with that. I agree with that conversation.Dominic Cummings’ influence in No 10 hasn’t been reined in“But this whole thing about ‘whacking’, about ‘it’s got hundreds of radio stations, and we’re going to close them down’. It doesn’t, it has 63, and so, therefore, the facts aren’t correct.“And there seems to be a sort of nasty streak behind some of these briefings. And if our whole mantra is to try and unite the country, after the difficulties we’ve had over the last couple of years – and this government has a mandate to do that – then I’m not sure why we need to be quite so isive in the tone and language that we’re using. title: dark waters true story film mark ruffalo anne hathaway
story: Once they dropped dead, the farmer decided to carry out his own autopsy and was petried after discovering their organs were mysteriously tinged green.The West Virginia-based farmer was convinced a toxic river that ran into his farmland was to blame, since the animals strange symptoms began when his brother sold some land to a chemical company to use as a landfill site a little further upstream.His fight to find out the truth - with the help of a lawyer called Rob Bilott - has been dramatised in new film Dark Waters, starring Mark Ruffalo and Anne Hathaway.The film recounts the shocking real le story of how an American company called DuPont had been slowly and knowingly poisoning a community of , people via the local water supply for almost half a century.A chemical they had been using to manufacture kitchenware products had seeped into the water via pipes that fed into the Ohio River that ran next to their plant and also by dumping landfill in unlined pits so that it fed into the soil and nearby water systems.It has since been linked to six diseases, including cancer, and birth defects - with one child born with a single nostril and a serrated eyelid - and is today present in the blood of millions who have either drunk contaminated water or used their products in cooking.Yet, when Wilbur confronted the company, he was simply told poor farming was to blame, and met with an audacious cover-up...Tennant and his four siblings were tragically forced to start a cattle farm with just seven cows after their father abandoned them.They slowly grew the herd to , and the animals grazed happily on more than  idyllic acres.The farmland shrunk, however, in the s when one of the sons, Jim, and his we Della sold  acres to the influential DuPont.Employing thousands of locals, the company operated the Washington Works plant in nearby Parkersburg that was  times the size of the Pentagon.They wanted to use the land for standard waste disposal, and named the plot Dry Run Landfill after the creek which ran through it and flowed into fields where the Tennants’ cattle grazed.Unknown to the family, the business was actually disposing of a dangerous chemical called PFOA - properly known as perfluorooctanoic acid - as a quick and cheap way of getting rid of it.Soon after Dupont began dumping the toxic sludge, the water began to take on a green, frothy consistency. Nearby trees started to look ashen.Before long, the cows, drinking from the water, started to change in appearance. They developed stringy tails, malformed hooves, huge legions in their coats, hair loss, humped backs, blackened teeth and receding eyes, and were plagued by constant diarrhoea and have thick white slime leaking from their mouths.Then they began acting strangely. Rather than walk over to be milked like usual, they’d aggressively charge - in an odd, bow-legged fashion - at the farmers and often have to be shot.One day, Tennant found two deer and two dead cattle not far from the river. Blood was inexplicably running from their noses and mouths. He also discovered a deceased calf with unusually bright blue eyes.After losing  of his herd, he decided to dissect the cattle to see what was going on inside. When he sliced open the organs - the liver, heart, stomachs, kidneys and gallbladder - they were discoloured green.Tennant raised the alarm in , approaching everyone from local lawyers and politicians to vets and doctors.Yet they were terried of going against the revered DuPont, who had given work to so much of the local community.Desperate, he turned to a lawyer called Bilott, an environmental lawyer at corporate Cincinnati firm Taft Stettinius  Hollister he had first met as a child.A sceptical Bilott agreed to meet the baseball cap-wearing farmer - but he was left aghast at the goings on at the farm, the evidence of which was shown to him on a homemade video tape.Tenannt told him that he thought something from DuPonts landfill site had contaminated the river water - and was poisoning his animals.‘‘There’s something really bad going on here, he later recalled, the New York Times reports. It just felt like the right thing to do. I felt a connection to those folks.’’But by agreeing to take on DuPont, the law firm was put in uncharted territory - they usually defended such chemical companies, rather than sued them.Bilott filed against DuPont in summer of . In response, the company sent a team of vets to the farm - whose report blamed the family for killing their livestock.This infuriated the Tennants, who were already being ostracised by the local community for daring to take on DuPont.People would walk out of restaurants when they entered. They had to change churches three times.Bilott waded through piles of documents, but could still find nothing to explain the dying herd. ‘‘We were getting frustrated,’’ he admitted.Then the lawyer stumbled across something he had never seen before in his entire career.Dupont had sent a letter to the Environmental Protection Agency mentioning a substance in the landfill called PFOA.A chemistry expert he had used put him on the right track - it was perfluorooctanoic acid.Bilott got a court order in the autumn of  that forced the company to hand over boxes of files, including confidential studies conducted by DuPont scientists.‘‘I started seeing a story,’’ Bilott said. ‘‘It became apparent what was going on: They had known for a long time that this stuff was bad.’’He discovered that in  Dupont began purchasing PFOA to use in the manufacturing of Teflon - the non-stick coating for pans and other cookware.Despite clear instructions that it be disposed of carefully, over several decades they pumped the excess powder through pipes into the Ohio River.They also dumped , tons of PFOA-laced sludge into ‘‘digestion ponds’’ - or unlined pits.This meant that the chemical could seep into the ground and straight into the local water supply.Clearly concerned about what they had been doing, DuPont commissioned medical studies on PFOA.They found it could increase the size of the liver in rats and rabbits, and that a high concentration had made it into the blood of employees.They also tested the children of pregnant employees in their Teflon ision - of seven births, two had eye defects. In  they realised that it was present in the water supply.A local woman called Darlene Kigerhad been married to a chemist at DuPont’s PFOA lab.She recalled how he would come home from work with fever, nausea, diarrhoea, vomiting - a group of ailments common among the workforce who nicknamed it Teflon flu.Aged , she had to have an emergency hysterectomy after warnings from her husband about washing his work clothes.She admitted: ‘‘I asked myself, what does DuPont have to do with our drinking water ’’Another person who appears as themselves in the new film is Bucky Bailey, , who was born with a single nostril and a deformed face.His mum had worked in direct contact with chemicals at DuPont. “They tried to blame me, telling me that it was something I did,” she told the "BBC last year.By the s, DuPont knew that PFOA - which had also been shown to be pretty much indestructible - caused cancerous testicular, pancreatic and liver tumours in lab animals, and a study linked it to testicular cancer in workers.Despite this, they dumped , tons of PFOA into Dry Run Landfill - and when they tested the water running into the Tennants’ land it contained dangerously high levels.They kept this knowledge a secret from both the public and the EPA for years.In August  the Tennants settled, but Bilott was still angry.“DuPont had for decades been actively trying to conceal their actions,” he said. “They knew this stuff was harmful, and they put it in the water anyway.And the lawyer was worried what it was doing to humans. He demanded that steps be taken to regulate PFOA and provide clean water to those living near the factory, and sent letters to key authorities.However, the problem was much bigger.Independent tests confirmed that PFOA was in the water supply being used by , people - and had been for decades. However, until it was recognised by the government as a toxin, it wasn’t illegal.In , the EPA released additional findings. It didn’t affect just those who drunk the contaminated local water, but also any members of the general public who cooked with Teflon kitchenware. PFOA had even been found in American blood banks.DuPont agreed in  to install filtration plants in the six affected water districts and to pay a cash award of m .After seven years, in , scientists revealed that there was a ‘‘probable link’’ between PFOA and six diseases - including kidney cancer, testicular cancer, thyroid disease, high cholesterol, pre-eclampsia and ulcerative colitis.Today, it is estimated by researchers that it is present in the blood of  per cent of Americans due to contamination of the water supply and from coming into contact with Teflon on multiple household products.PFOA is indestructible and will never disintegrate, and is part of a group of compounds used in manufacturing now called forever chemicals.DuPont opened a new facility in North Carolina to make PFOA and spun its activities into a new venture called Chemours.Last year, " reported that both companies - as well as a third M, who had supplied PFOA to DuPont initially - had denied before US lawmakers that they were responsible for contamination of toxic “forever chemicals”.Despite the reluctance of companies to accept wrongdoing, the local community had won.‘‘There was relief,’’ Bilott said. We were able to deliver what we had promised to these folks seven years earlier.Especially since, for all those years, DuPont had been saying that we were lying, trying to scare and mislead people.’’Dark Water is released in UK cinemas on Friday th February.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc licence fee leo mckinstry abolish
story: The creaking corporation is almost a century old, and nowhere is that more apparent than in its defence of the hopelessly outdated licence fee.The Beeb likes to pose as a beacon of fairness, yet it is subsidised by a draconian compulsory charge that should have no place in a modern free society.On pain of criminal prosecutions, all owners of television sets are forced to bankroll BBC staff, regardless of whether they ever use its services or not.Lets be clear: it is fundamentally wrong that people should have to pay for something they do not want.That is why the Government is right to consider the abolition of the licence fee within the next few years, moving to a subscription-based service.Such a move, which could happen before the BBC’s charter is renewed in , would be entirely in step with our times.After all, nearly half of British households already subscribe to streaming channels like Netflix. And more people now watch YouTube than all terrestrial broadcasters put together.Even the BBCs highest paid star, Gary Lineker, says its time to make the fee voluntary, while Dame Helen Mirren admits its had its day.Yet the Government’s policy has provoked howls of outrage, especially from the chattering liberals who seem to regard the licence fee as a sacred part of our constitution.Their squeals of protest are badly misplaced. The fact is that, by guaranteeing a huge revenue stream, the licence fee promotes a culture of excess and mismanagement within the BBC, which has a budget of almost £ billion and employs , people.Its reflected in the vast salaries paid to scores of BBC stars, far beyond market rates, like the £. million previously dished out to Lineker, £, to newsreader Huw Edwards, or the £, to sports presenter Jason Mohammad.You can spot it in the host of botched or extravagant schemes, like the notorious reconstruction of the EastEnders set, whose budget soared from £ million to £. million.Worse still, a staggering £ billion was spent on the refurbishment of Broadcasting House in central London.There is also absurd doubling up among staff, particularly in the news.Last week, the BBC had  correspondents covering the American Democrat primaries in Iowa and New Hampshire, while in  no fewer than  on-air journalists were sent to report on one brief Brussels summit attended by David Cameron.But the lack of any commercial pressure is most easily spotted in the vast, sprawling tiers of flabby bureaucracy.Ab Fab comedian Jenner Saunders once said of the corporation, “It’s become top-heavy in such an ugly way,” adding that it is “an executive-run place for idiots”.A glance through the BBC’s Annual Report for  shows just how correct she was.On these pages, I counted no fewer than eight managers who had “Human Resources Director” in their job titles, all of them on at least £,-a-year.Among them were: Dale Haddon, “HR Director, News and Employee Relations”, on up to £, Rachel Currie, “BBC Group HR Director” on up to £, and Gillian Taylor, “HR Director” on £,.It was the same story with BBC News, whose regiment of well-healed officials included: Fran Unsworth, the “Director of News” on £, Gavin Allen, “Head of News Output” on £, and Jonathan Munroe, Head of Newsgathering” on £,.This grasping spirit prevails throughout the bloated organisation, from the £, “Director of Nations and Regions” to the £, “Director of Radio and Education.”Insulated by public funding, the corporation adores both navel-gazing and self-promotion. So it has a “Director of Communications” on £,-a-year, a “Director of Policy” on £, and a “Director of Editorial Policy” on £,.All that puts into perspective the current moans from the BBC about the need for cuts.But apart from the managerial excess, what also aggravates is how the corporation uses its publicly-funded muscle to promote a fashionable, London-centric agenda.As the state’s monopoly broadcaster, the BBC should be utterly impartial.Yet its output is dominated by trendy political messages on immigration, climate change, Tory cuts, ersity and poverty.The BBC might have lavished reporters on the Democrat primaries, but it gave hardly any live coverage to the recent celebrations in Parliament Square at the moment of Brexit.Typically a Newsnight discussion  that evening – held in a studio bedecked with the blue and gold of the EU - featured two Remainers and one Brexiteer.Left-wing propaganda is continually crowbarred into everything from drama to discussion programmes.Just  per cent of the national workforce is employed in the public sector, yet the BBC is filled with the voices of state employees, most of them whining about under-funding.Left-wing opinions have a stranglehold most topical comedy shows, such as Radio Four’s News Quiz, hosted by the achingly unfunny Nish Kumar.It was Kumar who recently caused a storm by sneeringly presenting an edition of the BBC children’s show “Horrible Histories”, in which Britain’s Victorian past was held up for ridicule.The BBC can get away with this because of its lucrative monopoly as the state’s only broadcaster. It has abused that privileged position for too long.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the bbc is untrustworthy licence fee choice
story: THE culture war over the BBC licence fee is in full force.And predictably the usual campaign from the typical Beeb scare mongers has begun.So let me start by saying: No one is suggesting closing the BBC. No one is suggesting you won’t have Strictly Come Dancing or Match of the Day or even Question Time and Newsnight.But the media is fundamentally changing. Consumer choice – what you or me choose to consume on the box or on our iPads or phones and at what time – is king.The idea that by  paying £. for a service that we may choose not to watch or listen to AT ALL is insanity.It might be unpleasant for BBC lers but the time has come to accept that the licence fee must evolve into a subscription service, so that the corporation is accountable to viewers and not the current behemoth that puts local newspapers out of business, that competes with national newspaper websites to write about Love Island, and that makes podcasts like Reality Tea all about the MTV reality series Geordie Shore.That is NOT public service broadcasting. It is a blatant and constant attempt to undercut struggling commercial rivals.But a sea change is coming. I truly feel it.Sure, there might be disagreement at Downing Street about exactly what that change will involve.Personally I’m on the side of Dominic Cummings who wants wholescale cuts. Sell Radio  and Radio , shut down the sweeping BBC Online department and focus on true public service programming that won’t be provided where. Then in  allow people the choice about whether they want to pay for what they watch from the BBC or not.But the plan by Boris Johnson - who The Times reports this morning fancies an evolution not a revolution - is also valid. The first step to decriminalise the licence fee is the start of bringing the BBC back in line.The fact we’re even having this discussion is the fault of the BBC, which has proven itself to be untrustworthy and lacking in political impartiality in recent years.It disgraced itself over its coverage of Brexit. It proved it was no longer in touch with vast swathes of the country the folk outside of London who don’t spend their days eating quinoa salads and quaffing champagne with other members of the liberal media elite.It proved itself out of touch for failing to predict the biggest story at the most recent election: Boris Johnson’s historic toppling of Labour’s northern red wall.But what’s most telling story: They may be targeted in the Budget as Boris Johnson’s all- powerful adviser Dominic Cummings eyes up a £billion spending pot.He wants to end the fuel duty freeze, which has been in place since  and saves drivers about £. every time they fill up.The tax will probably go up by the rate of inflation, putting p on a litre of fuel.However, the rise might be delayed until next year.Mr Cummings wants to use fuel tax to fund the PM’s promised spending on infrastructure outside the capital, Treasury sources say.Some in No believe it will also boost the Tories’ reputation on the environment.Fuel duty was frozen thanks to The Sun’s long-running Keep it Down campaign. title: greece britain elgin marbles
story: We face having tothe Elgin Marbles — the collection of sculptures originally created by the ancient Greek architect Phidias and his assistants — under a free trade deal with the EU.Greece, which has long demanded we give these treasures up, has insisted a clause about theirbe inserted into any agreement.If you have ever seen the Elgin Marbles, you will understand what all the fuss is about. They are simply stunning.It’s no wonder that the Greeks want them to be ed to Athens while we want to keep them.They are on display for free in the British Museum, and I would urge you to pay them a visit.You cannot help but be moved by the amazing level of craftsmanship and imagination embodied in them.The outstanding sculptures depict, in expressive detail, rippling muscles, bulging veins, fluttering robes, the flaring nostrils of horses and the upward swing of a bull’s head in a flowing, dynamic composition that reveals the extraordinary skill of their creators.They have inspired artists in their depiction of the human and animal form since they were rediscovered in the th Century.To have them here in Britain, in the care of the British Museum since , is an enormous privilege, never to be taken for granted.We are lucky that Lord Elgin found them and made a deal with the local Ottoman rulers at the time to bring so many of them back to the UK in the early s.At the time, the Parthenon was no longer the awe-inspiring temple it had been.In fact, it had been badly damaged in an explosion in , and when Lord Elgin took them, many of the marbles were little more than rubble.Since being housed in the British Museum, among other stunning treasures from the ancient world, public understanding of their signicance has grown.They continue to inspire anyone who sees them with a sense of what human beings can achieve in the application of knowledge, imagination and skill.At the British Museum, which is legally obliged to care for them in perpetuity, they can be visited and studied by adults, children and young people from all over the country.Not all of us will be lucky enough to travel to Greece in our letime but your mind can wander there by seeing the Elgin Marbles in London.And it is important that our kids continue to do this, because it opens up the history of the world and art.It is not just Brits either. London is one of the most accessible cities in the world, easy to reach from across Europe and where.People from around the globe visit the museum and learn what we share in common, and how humans have interpreted the world through their artefacts.We should resist the claim that artefacts belong where they were made, not least because it denies historical truth.Throughout history, artefacts have been traded across the world, often to the benefit of the people who created them, sometimes to their detriment. History is complicated and often not to our liking.The Parthenon was built long before modern Greece existed — when the region was made up of warring cities ided by arid mountains.Those who built the Parthenon had no notion of nationhood. Their concern at the time would have been to show off their city.How proud they would have beenthey could have foreseen the reverence with which their creations are held today around the world.The fact that the DNA of their descendants is now likely to have spread worldwide only reinforces the point that the geographical origin of the Marbles carries little objective signicance.Giving in to repatriation demands will undo the real achievements of cultural history in showing that more unites us than ides us. The amazing thing about the flowering of knowledge about the world in the th and th Centuries was that it created an awareness of human potential — a sense of what we could achieve in the arts and sciences.The Marbles symbolise this achievement — they opened up horizons and revealed new possibilities for human thought and action.Maintaining this sense of openness remains as important now as ever.In today’s globalised world, it’s tempting to think that people can see anything via the internet,not physically.But we must fiercely guard our museum collections, which remain the most accessible way for properly engaging with history.The Government is right to refuse to include the Elgin Marbles in any deals with the EU.They should never be used as political capital to serve the interests of European elites.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Government forces, backed by Russian allies, are currently moving into the northwestern city of Idlib, which contains the last rebel fighters opposing the rule of President Bashar al-Assad.The offensive, which began on December , has seen heavy shelling of civilian areas and displaced around , people.It comes at the end of a nine-year civil war that began when protests that sprang up as part of the Arab Springs in  were violently suppressed by government forces.In an interview with Sky News, UN Deputy Regional Humanitarian Coordinator for Syria Mark Cutts warned of the mass loss of innocent lethe offensive is allowed to continue.There are about a million displaced people living in camps and makesht shelters in that area andthe shelling and airstrikes move any further into that area were going to see a bloodbath, he said.Were going to see a massacre on a scale that has never been seen in this entire war.I had men and women in this meeting crying.The translator broke down into tears explaining what is going on in the area. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn overweight mum lost  stone in as many weeks and claims she reversed her pre-diabetes after switching to a apossmartapos weight-loss plan - which allowed her to eat chocolate and drink wine. Tipping the scales at st lbs, Lynne Gaskell, , from Lancashire, was determined to lose weight so she “could be around for longer” to look after her autistic son Joshua. After being told she was pre-diabetic during a full health MOT when she turned , Lynne knew it was time to act. She started researching ways to get into shape and put herself forward for the Second Nature programme, a -week programme which focuses on ‘rewiring’ people’s habits to live healthier lives. She said: The results of the blood test showed I was at risk of type  diabetes and they classed me as pre-diabetic. They said the best thing for me to do was to lose weight. “I didn’t want to join a gym or any of the slimming groups as they didn’t appeal to me. “My son Joshua is autistic and needs a lot of care. He was one of the reasons why it was important to become healthier.” After signing up to the digital-focused plan, Lynne was a set of ‘smart’ scales and an activity tracker that links with the app, allowing her to monitor her weight-loss progress and daily step count.  She was also sent a recipe book, a meal plan and daily motivational articles, and was added to an online peer support group - hosted by a qualied dietitian offering daily advice. The digital aspect meant she still had the motivation to shed the pounds without having to stand up in front of a room of strangers and talk about her weight. She said: I lost weight straight away. It’s really easy to stick to and because I’m eating healthily, my husband, Lee, is too - he’s lost two stone.  “The biggest change I’ve made is creating meal plans and sticking to the meals, using their recipes and keeping a food diary.” She swapped fast food for freshly cooked dishes, including a number of delicious treats like chocolate-covered desserts, muffins and curries. She was also told that nothing was off limits, meaning she could treat herself to the odd glass of wine. She said: “I really don’t feel as though I’m missing out on anything - and I’ve cooked things I wouldn’t normally cook. The things we do like eating, we’ve found an alternative way of cooking them, or substituted it with something . “There’s nothing you can’t have as long as you have it in moderation or that you’re very mindful that what you’re having is a treat.  “On a Friday night, my husband and I will sometimes have a bottle of wine with our neighbours or we’ll enjoy a takeaway - I will choose a healthier option though. “I’ve given some of my recipes to my father-in-law, who is diabetic, and my mother-in-law who is at risk - and she’s lost lbs.” Lynne also started walking every day, slowly at first, beginning with , steps, gradually increasing it to , over the duration of the -week programme. Lynne has stopped an incredible st and now weighs st lbs, saying the weightloss has also helped ease the pain of the arthritis she has in her knee. Sheaposs also bought herself a dog, and walking Aubrey gives her a reason to get out exercising over the weekend.  She said: I’ve wanted a dog all my married le, but my husband always used to say that I would never walk it or take care of it. But after I’d lost a couple of stone, he agreed that I could get a puppy. “I have a beautul chocolate labrador called Aubrey - she’s  weeks now and she is taken for walks all the time. Having a dog helps me to get out at the weekend. “My son is overweight too - because of his autism, he has a very restricted diet and we have to stick to very specic things. So it’s been great for us to take the dog out together for a couple of hours. “I’m now much more active with him over the weekends. But le hasn’t hugely changed - which is a good thing. It just means I have the peace of mind of knowing I will be around for a lot longer for Josh - and be healthier around him.  “I’ve just had my yearly check up and the results from my blood tests is perfect - my sugar levels are fine and I’m no longer at risk of type- diabetes. Second Nature was set up by Chris Edson and Mike Gibbs — both former NHS advisors — to tackle Britainaposs obesity and type- diabetes epidemic. The programme, which offers an effective alternative to fasting, calorie counting and points- based diets, has so far amassed , users and is also being trialled by the NHS. Chris Edson, co-founder of Second Nature, said: “We’ve used our research and insights to create an app that helps you rewire your habits.  “Using smart behavioural science, our app makes it easy for you to form new habits, ones that help you sleep better, eat better and feel better. Habits that help you lose weight, and keep it off. “As habit experts, we know the key to changing them successfully is keeping it up, long-term. So, we stay by your side, in your pocket, helping you keep up these positive changes for good. “In the end, you’ll find you’re not trying to lose weight, you’re not depriving yourself or counting calories, you’re just living better, automatically, every day.”

story: NewsMum begs pharmaceutical company to give her son, , le-saving wonderdrugJoe Barnes mum Lorraine, from Barnes, is desperate for the drug company Vertex to grant her dying son Trikafta on compassionate grounds - as he cannot currently receive it on the NHSShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  FEB NewsJoe Barnes mum thinks Trikafta could save his le" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFor Joe Barnes’ mum, one word means everything. Trikafta. The wonder drug Lorraine believes could save her son’s le. Yesterday, Health Secretary Matt Hancock announced he has ­accelerated the process to get Trikafta agreed by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence to treat cystic fibrosis . It’s excellent news for thousands with CF, but has only compounded the agony for Joe’s family. NICE’s planned timelines for assessing the triple combination therapy show they expect to publish their recommendation on December  this year. That will be too late for Joe whose doctors have already begun to talk to his family about starting end-of-le care. So today, Lorraine is making a plea directly to the drug company Vertex to grant her dying son Trikafta now, on compassionate grounds. “Vertex,you have any compassion at all, you won’t let my amazing son die,” Lorraine says. “Help me get Trikafta for Joe… I don’t know what  can help him now.” I first spoke to Lorraine and Joe two years ago in March  when they were fighting for the le-changing drug Orkambi. Joe was  and extremely unwell. Orkambi wasn’t available then on the NHS because of its hefty price tag, and the Barnes family were among those fighting a three-year battle to get Vertex, NHS England and NICE to agree a deal so it could be prescribed in the UK. The Orkambi campaign was ­eventually successful, with the drug finally made available in the UK last October, but campaign group Just Treatment believe up to  people may have died waiting for the row to be resolved.Orkambi helped Joe for a while, but he is now extremely ill again, and all the evidence suggests Trikafta could help. So now his exhausted family are facing another David and Goliath fight for a tiny pill that couldsave their son’s le. Currently, there is no cure for CF and half of people in the UK with it die before they are . The le-limiting condition clogs the lungs with sticky mucus as well as affecting other organs. But in the very few cases in the UK where Trikafta has been made available, they have had almost miraculous results. “Joe is too poorly for a lung ­transplant,” Lorraine says. “He can’t go to school, he gets breathless just going upstairs. He’s suffering with chest pains, coughing up blood, he can’t gain weight, he’s depressed. He’s gone through more in his  years that most people will go through in a letime.” Lorraine says Joe’s doctor is in the process of applying for compassionate Trikafta for her son and seven other patients, but that the ­paperwork is prohibitive. “It took his doctor  hours spread over six weeks to fill in one form,” she says. “If there are eight to apply for that will take  weeks to get through them all and then it’s up to Vertex who gets the drug.” Trikafta campaigners know the drugs are expensive, but say the cost is nothing compared with the cost to the NHS of looking after a child going through end-stage CF. CF accounts for , hospital admissions and over , hospital bed days a year. Treatment can easily take four hours a day including physiotherapy, and patients can be on up to  tablets every day. A spokeswoman for Vertex said: “Triple combination therapy is not yet licensed in the EU, and we are restricted by law in how and to whom we can supply this potential medicine in a compassionate use programme.

story: NewsSketches by young Queen Liz valued at £, and display precocious talentCritics say the drawings display considerable talent and suggest that her le could have taken an artistic turn had she not taken over as reigning monarch in ShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  FEB NewsTwo charming sketches purported to be the work of Queen Elizabeth II " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwo sketches believed to be made by the Queen when she was a child are set to sell for thousands. Critics say the works display a “precocious talent” and experts value them at a minimum of £,. Buckingham Palace last night refused to confirm whether the art was genuine. One pencil sketch shows a middle-aged women in profile while the other seems to be of the same person knitting. The woman is believed to be Marion Crawford, tutor to the future Queen and her sister Princess Margaret. Drawn on royal-headed paper, they were found inside a book called The Scottish National War Memorial. The inside page is signed “Elizabeth” in blue ink. Art critic Philip Mould said: “If these are by the Queen they show a pre­­cocious talent that, had she not become sovereign, could have taken her in artistic directions. “The only person likely to establish authenticity for certain, however, is the artist herself.”Although the date  is stamped on the book, the Queen would have been just six at the time and experts suggest the drawings could date from later. A private collector sent them to auctioneers William George of Peter­­­borough, Cambs. The firm’s Alex McCormick said: “It is most likely they were drawn by a member of the royal family close to Elizabeth, or perhaps even by the future Queen herself.”

The duo were encouraged into the rehabilitation sanctuaryaposs aposforest schoolapos so Anggun could re-learn the natural behaviours of climbing, foraging for food and making nests which are essential for survival in the forests. This proves that, even when orangutans like Monti lose their mothers at a very young age, they are still able to be good mothers, not just with their own children, but also with other baby orangutans. Animal volunteers travelled for three days to the release point at the heart of the national park - transporting the orangutans over a -mile road trip which was followed by an hour-long boat journey and finally a five and a half mile walk. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGovernment chiefs in Ibiza and Mallorca are cracking down on boozy Britsapos drunken tourism by limiting the number of drinks holidaymakers in all-inclusive hotels can have per day. In a move which the British Association of Travel Agentshas slammed has blasted as misdirected, the Balearic Government has passed a new law allowing just six drinks a day to be served at all-inclusive hotels. This will affect tourists in Arenal and Magaluf in Mallorca and in the West End of San Antonio in Ibiza. It will apply to any new bookings at all-inclusive hotels from now on, and will limit Brits to three free drinks at lunch and three with their evening meal. Balearic chiefs say they want to improve the image of these three party resorts which have been blighted by bad behaviour, usually caused by too much drink. The new legislation has also introduced big fines for aposbalconingapos - jumping into a swimming pool from a hotel balcony. There will be a ban on pub crawls and drink offers such as happy hours and two for ones, which reports say have been welcomed. But the alcohol limit in all-inclusive hotels has caused controversy. The ABTA is asking the Balearic Government to think again about this element of the campaign. A spokesperson said: The Balearic Islands and the destinations of Magaluf and San Antonio are very popular with British holidaymakers. While we strongly support initiatives that improve the health and safety of holidaymakers, as well as the welfare of local communities, such as encouraging bar owners to take a more responsible approach to the sale of alcohol and campaigning for balcony safety among young holidaymakers, we believe some of the measures announced in relation to addressing unsociable behaviour, for example targeting all-inclusive holidays, are misdirected. The vast majority of holidaymakers on all-inclusives are couples and families, so it is dficult to see how imposing strict rules on this type of arrangement will fix the problem of anti-social behaviour in resort. We would encourage the Balearic authorities to reconsider this.  “It’s also important to highlight that the limits on drinks does not apply to all-inclusive holidays that have already been booked in these resorts.” The six-a-day limit does not apply to any of the all-inclusive hotels outside of Arenal, Magaluf and San Antonio. Hotel owners are said to be worried and claim tourists are already shunning their establishments and opting for those outside the zones so they can enjoy unlimited booze like before. In some cases, they say, the hotels are just yards apart but not within the target zones of Arenal, Magaluf and San Antonio.  The new regulations will be valid for five years, with breaches leading to a penalty-based-system of fines of up to €, and suspension of activity for up to three years. Contracts already signed between tour operators and hoteliers will be respected to prevent any legal or contractual issues. A spokesperson for the Balearic Government said: The Balearic Islands government has approved a Decree Law to combat alcohol excess in certain tourist areas, with the aim of forcing real change in the tourism model of these destinations promoting responsible conduct, adopting measures to protect the destination and avoiding issues derived from excessive alcohol consumption in certain places of the Balearic Islands.
